sources.title: How to Use Your Smartphone to Cope With Hearing Loss
sources.snippet: This comprehensive guide from WIRED explains how smartphones can assist individuals with hearing loss through a range of built-in and downloadable features on iPhone and Android devices. With hearing loss affecting 13% of U.S. adults and expected to affect one in four people globally by 2050, tools to aid communication and hearing awareness are increasingly vital. The article details features such as Apple’s Live Captions (currently in beta), Google’s Live Caption and Live Transcribe, sound recognition tools for detecting alarms and doorbells, and audio tuning through headphones or hearing aids. It highlights accessibility tools like Conversation Mode on Pixel devices and Real-Time Text (RTT) or Teletype (TTY) for voice calls. Apple’s Sound Recognition can detect specific custom sounds, and both platforms offer customization for noise filtering and amplification. The guide also advises on hearing loss prevention and explains why some tools are native only to Pixel devices. Overall, the article provides practical, up-to-date resources for integrating hearing assistance tools into everyday smartphone use.

citation_mappings.claim_text: Here are ways to get live transcription/captions while watching online videos or streaming — options work on desktop and phones: 1) Built-in live captions Android & Chrome: Live Caption (system feature) auto-generates captions for any audio playing on the device/browser, including streaming videos — works offline too. WIRED

sources.title: How to Use an iPhone to Transcribe Voice Memos and Lectures
sources.snippet:
This article provides a comprehensive guide on using various iPhone tools and apps to transcribe voice memos and lectures. It introduces four main methods: Evernote, Rev Voice Recorder, Aiko, and Apple’s built-in Live Captions.

Evernote allows both real-time recording and transcription of audio files (except M4A format) with a simple button click. The free version supports file sizes up to 25MB, while the Personal version allows up to 200MB. 

Rev Voice Recorder, a premium app, offers transcription services via human or AI and supports Zoom integration. Users can transcribe both new and existing recordings, though credits are needed for full access.

Aiko is a free, simple app that can transcribe live and pre-recorded voice memos but may crash when used in the background. It allows easy saving and sharing of transcriptions.

Lastly, iOS 16 and later versions feature Live Captions, a native, real-time transcription tool available through Accessibility settings, supporting English (US/Canada).

These solutions offer users flexibility depending on their transcription needs and app preferences.

citation_mappings.claim_text: iPhone / iPad / Mac: Live Captions in Accessibility shows real-time speech text over any audio playing. Lifewire

sources.title: Live Caption for Free | Maestra
sources.snippet: Particularly live streams can benefit from Maestra’s free live captioning tool by connecting their OBS or vMix accounts to instantly caption their content. With over 125 languages supported, users can target any language they want and create translated captions in real time to reach audiences otherwise unreachable by using the free web captioner.

citation_mappings.claim_text: 2) Browser extensions / web tools Maestra Live Caption / web captioner: real-time speech-to-text overlay on video/audio in your browser (Chrome). Works across platforms and supports many languages. Maestra AI

citation_mappings.claim_text: 4) Platform-specific captions YouTube / YouTube Live: many streams have auto-captions you can turn on inside the player itself (if enabled by creator). Zoom / Teams / streaming services: some have built-in live captions for meetings/watch parties. How they work (practical) For browser/Chrome features, just enable live captions in settings and play the video — text appears automatically. For apps like Otter or Live Transcribe, allow mic access; play the video loud enough or use internal audio routing so the tool can pick up sound and convert it to text. Otter.ai
